modules.description: This module manages SVM models, providing operations to inspect model properties such as type, number of classes, labels, and support vectors. It supports loading and saving models to files, and retrieving statistical information like class distribution and SVR probability estimates. Concrete use cases include persisting trained models to disk, analyzing model structure, and extracting metadata for evaluation or reporting.

This module represents a machine learning problem instance for support vector machines, encapsulating training data and target values. It supports sparse and dense input formats through `create` and `create_dense`, and provides operations to load, save, scale, and inspect the data. Use cases include preparing datasets for SVM training, normalizing feature ranges, and persisting problem state to disk.

This module evaluates the performance of a support vector machine model by comparing predicted values against expected values. It provides functions to calculate accuracy, mean squared error, squared correlation coefficient, and the number of correct predictions, all using vectors from the Lacaml library. These metrics are used to assess classification and regression tasks after model inference on test datasets.

This module implements support vector machine operations for classification and regression, supporting training with various SVM types and kernels, cross-validation, and prediction on sparse or dense data. It works with labeled datasets represented as arrays of sparse vectors or Lacaml dense vectors, enabling concrete applications such as text classification and numerical regression. The module includes a submodule for managing SVM models, allowing inspection of properties like type, labels, and support vectors, as well as loading, saving, and retrieving statistics. Another submodule encapsulates SVM problem instances, supporting creation, loading, saving, and scaling of training data in both sparse and dense formats.

This module provides tools for building, evaluating, and managing support vector machine models for classification and regression tasks. It supports training with different SVM types and kernels, cross-validation, prediction on sparse or dense data, and performance evaluation using metrics like accuracy, mean squared error, and squared correlation coefficient. Users can create and manipulate SVM models and problem instances, load and save models or training data, and inspect model properties such as support vectors and labels. Specific applications include text classification with sparse data and numerical regression with dense vectors.
